pros:
IBM is the most innovative company on this planet. I feel so proud to be a part of this technology company that helped landing man on the moon ! The depth of knowledge is so deep and vast that when I get into IBM, I feel like entering a global University. Unlimited learning and huge opportunities. The culture is amazing, the work content is always very satisfying and there is never a stagnation. We can keep rotating to different jobs within the company.

In this digital age, the contribution of IBM is so key to the society. The advent of Quantum computing and IBM’s promise to invest 20Bil in the next 10 years is just amazing. I am sure we will be leading the technology of the world, transforming our future generations. 

If we see the 100+ years of IBM’s journey, the company has sustained many market disruptions, reinvented itself many times and stood solid throughout. 

When I look back on my long career in IBM, I feel that it is just yesterday ! I am very proud to be a part of the great company. 

Long live IBM.

review_title: Different from what I was thinking
pros: - I thought IBM was old-school, traditional, and unattractive. But once I joined here almost 1.5 years, I loved this place. There are many things I can learn, hands-on with the most advanced technology in the market and open for a new joiner like me to share. - IBM culture is also perfect for me. We help each other open-mind, coaching and mentoring. - Chance to explore new things that I wanted to explore. My boss is also open to discussion and can argue with different opinions. - Compensation and benefit are fair and good for me. - The strategy from management is clear. It was one of the reasons why I chose IBM because of the hybrid cloud strategy.
cons: - From the technology perspective, I think it should be more open. I knew IBM tried so hard to make the solution compatible with open-source. But it should be easy to access by the external learner and easy to learn.

review_title: An antique company desperately trying to stay relevant.
pros: – Work-life balance is moderately alright (but ultimately depends on the project).
cons:
– Management gives absolutely no interest in your career goals & aspirations: often empty promises & lip services. Neither do they check-in with you to understand you better nor your current progress. 
– Way too many mid-management whom no one seems know what they are doing all day except for attending meetings. Too few hands-on staff to carry out the real work
– Compensation is below market rates for tech roles. Moreover YOY salary increment, as well as promotion, is negligible. 
– Benefits are non-existent. Annual paid-leave are minimal. 
– While local mentorship + networking is a common practice in most MNCs, it's a fairy-tale here. 
– Interview process has regressed in terms of rigour, resulting in many incompetent IT "talents" populating the workplace in the last 2 years.
– Overuse of (cheaper) employees who came from a career-switch background who are not quite yet experienced in running the show. 
– Projects are poorly executed: what was sold to clients hardly match with the reality on the ground.
– Attrition rate is really high for technical staff: knowledge transfer & hand-take are frequent, resulting in many messy sub-projects.

review_title: Unprofessional experience with Singapore IBM interview/ offer stage for delivery manager
pros: The interview was well conducted with relevant questions on skills and experience
cons:
After 3 interviews over a span of 1 month period, I was eventually informed that I successfully pass through the interview and was selected. I was excited and eagerly waiting for my offer and final signing of contract, but it never came. 

I was told that they don't have the budget to pay my salary after waiting for another month! The recruiter went on to tell me to wait even further for "their business people to discuss further" and they never did reply me to confirm anything. IBM recruiter then ignore my call and email to follow up on my case. 

This was very disappointing and frustrating. This happened to me despite me telling IBM my current pay and expected new salary right from the start. This is ridiculous and I totally did not expect such bad experience from a global company like IBM.

job_title: Service Delivery Manager (Strategic Outsourcing) in Singapore
pros:
-Great learning experience due to exposure to wide range of situations and challenges
-Adoption of industry standard best practices and processes (see cons for executions of said processes)
-Management is usually supportive when help is needed.
cons:
-Processes are poorly designed and there is a large amount of overlapping between many processes. The same information gets repeated in web portals, spreadsheets and powerpoints just to satisfy the whims of some bureaucrat. It is beyond ridiculous that I was spending 50-60% of my time filling up reports and working through bureaucracy and red tape.
-Management is so detached they do not have a clue of the challenges faced by ground troops. 
-Compensation compares poorly with competitors and non-vendor companies. Very difficult to hold on to talented people.
-Work life balance: what work life balance?

review_title: Does value people. Some concepts gone wrong.
pros:
- Company does value people (as compared to other service providers).
- Salary is ok but benefits are rather good.
- You get to work with the occasionally brilliant people.
- Pretty good global brand name.
cons:
- If you are in an account, you get affected by the crap in the account (basically passed down from the customer).
- If you are not in any account, you get the IBM billing crap. Bosses want you to do stuff but refuse to give you codes to bill your time to to cut costs. Said bosses at the end of the month will then come and hound you on why you have insufficient billed time.
- Too much information that needs to be collated and reported to higher ups; no sanity checks done on why the same information has to be reported to different teams in different templates.
- People who tend to go far in IBM are usually those who put in 200% and basically has no life outside work.
- More and more good people moving to other positions or leaving company, leaving with imbeciles that you have to work with.

review_title: A traditional IT company with declining performance everyday
pros: It's a good company for fresh graduates with degree from prestigious universities because the company pays well for fresh graduates and the company values colleague degree very much. You have a good environment to focus on doing research and development. Flexible working hours, work from home, and the company gradually realises its problems and improves its culture and efficiency.
cons: The direction of the company is changing all the time. It recently transform itself to cloud and analytics - these value added services and markets, but the competitors in these fields are also very strong, making the company struggling and its revenue also declining. That's why the growth of employee's salary is very slow. The employee's benefits are also getting worse. The learning experience in the company is more towards around theory like proof of concepts and making hypothesis and assumptions. What's lacking is those practical skills and knowledge and real world problems and solutions. Although generally speaking, the company is still making profit, it has 20 consecutive quarterly revenue decline, which also affect the morale of the staff.

review_title: There are only 2 roles in this complex organisation.. salesman or others.
pros:
- Good work benefits i.e work from home policy
- Great / recognized brand name
- Forgiving company...Room to learn and grow 
- Huge company so risks are spread out
- Good training (if you are a campus hire)
cons:
- Extremely complex structure 
- Difficult to understanding multiple offerings and clarity of roles
- Top heavy... as many generals as there are soldiers
- bureaucracy at its prime i.e many approving layers for simple tasks, pricing
- Lower pay than competitiors
- Too much reporting, each employee has at least 3 managers (because there are too many generals!)
- Obsession with pipeline, quarter after quarter reviews
- There are only 2 roles, you are either in sales or others. Needless to say, only sales are valued employees
- slow career progression

review_title: Can an organisation like IBM be guilty of irresponsible hiring?
pros: It has stature and repute, a seemingly forward looking culture and a professional management that is seemingly competent; at least that's how it looks from the outside.
cons: It's quite different once you're inside.  For one, management didn't have clear and defined requirements of my job when they were hiring, which in retrospect it has misrepresented the job role and content at the point when I signed up for the job.

job_title: Project Manager Service Management in Singapore
pros: A Global company - that gives the freedom to learn and move laterally or vertically. The amount of learning made available (some of them with a cost) is UN-paralleled. The push to capture ideas, internal learning, sharing best practices and recognition for the same has never been more intense.
cons:
The constantly increasing pressure to deliver in an environment of UN-explained cost cuts has dampened a lot of enthusiasm and drive to work "for" the company. 
Although I've not lost faith in the company's goal or working in IBM a thing of pride, the environment down under is enough to kill most people's respect, can't blame them for moving out.

review_title: Good start for career but bad for a long term growth with the company due to management
pros:
- Meet talented people who are willing to share their knowledge and experience
- IBM worldwide reputation
- Great opportunities to learn and grow
cons:
- Bell curve performance management(many members works overtime/on weekend but there is still a need to have  "average contributors" and "below contributors")
- No proper training is provided for the growing sectors since they can fire the unwanted members and hire new members at anytime.
- Try to cut cost at every corner which brings down the quality
- Care more about profit/revenue than talented people they should keep
- Office politics

review_title: Best of IBM is the BEST!
pros:
IBM is a great company to work with. It's open door policy, allows employee to walk into anyone's cubicle including the top of the organization to have a transparent discussion and share ideas. 
IBM recognises top 1000 contributors each year who have demonstrated leadership in 'delivering client values' and contributed towards IBM's growth. This is called "Best of IBM"  or in other words "Club of one thousand" award. It has been great privileged for me to get recognised this year; and be part of the success celebration. IBM Honouree is allowed to bring his/her partner to this event where employee get a chance to meet colleagues from other part of the world and other business units. This also foster collaboration and belongingness. 
The key aspect of this event is; IBM recognises employee's partner/spouse/parents for employee's success and hence IBM's success.
cons: It is too big and hence complex

pros: Good work balance and flexible working environment. The company is good for young family employees. Culture is decent. Co-workers are generally good people to work with. Good benefits but not bonuses
cons: Process of staff utilization is suck. Staff is penalized because billable hours clocked low below 20% and blamed for not get project to be assigned. In fact, the mgmt forgotten that professional services team is only implementation not sales or responsible to get deals or projects. Time sheet utilization is not supposed to be measured as overall performance of the staff. Local management should be more supportive to team who did work for customers satisfaction and completing the project and not blindly to chasing the numbers to make themselves look in senior or HQ board of directors.

pros:
Good people to work with
Good to build a large network and make friends
People generally helpful
Looks good on a CV
cons:
They might be the lowest paying tech giant out there so a lot of people treat it as a temporary work place to put that big name on their CV
Loyal employees are not getting nearly what they actually deserve
When they decide to move to another country, don't expect much cushioning (if any)

pros: Knowledge sharing - some good training/knowledge such as defect prevention process & 7 keys to success in project management (part of project management fundamental course)
cons:
Too much of processes!

The implementation of GDF/Lean is more of a management reporting to the global, rather than understand what is happening on the ground.

Just ask any ground staff in IBM who is involved in GDF/lean and you will know the staff's morale is at all time low.

Even with the name of 'global', it's more of a few line summary of what to do.

On how to implement it and with what tool - You figure out yourself.

That's why it's a Global Disaster Framework.

review_title: Join for the resume. Leave when you've found an actual career.
pros:
- Looks good on resume: Word is 80% of the next hiring managers are clueless about the mediocrity of IBM and the real 'work' you get to do. The rest were either ex-IBM or have worked with IBM before and are more aware
- Plenty of opportunities for daily afternoon masala chai
- Colored glasses for promotions, works to your favor if you are on the ends of the spectrum
cons:
- Mind-numbing work, services going downhill
- Smart folks have left so that means you get to work alongside the unexceptional ones settling for the free money. Not that there's anything wrong about that, free money is always good
- Overall, best place to grow old (while watching paint dry)

review_title: Bruising and challenging times be expected
pros: Flexible working hours and mobile work policy
cons: Pretty much everything else, poor pay, long working hours, heavy politicking and need to be in the right clique to get ahead.  Very segmented and no ownership culture...people are afraid to speak up as they will be asked to do more work.  Middle management expected to motivate junior staff but are undermined with global initiatives, with no feedback sought or encouraged.

cons:

review_title: So much hype about "New IBM" - Lost what made people proud of "Old IBM"
pros: Lots of opportunities to travel, work with different clients, try new industries, be put in situations where you could
cons: Cost cutting, ruthless focus on utilisation, lack of training, no support for junior staff to grow their skills and deliver the level of quality expected of "consultants". Would get sent out on over-promised projects totally unqualified for what you were sold as, with no back-up, set up to fail, under-deliver almost constantly.

review_title: "We're IBMers, we have no life, and no money!" is the running joke here.
pros:
The attitude and capability of the majority are good. There are a couple of incompetent basket cases that you will learn to handle, but on the whole the people are great. 

The culture is easy going amongst the grunt worker bees, and also allows for flexible working hours (although that might depend on your manager and/or department). The medical benefits are great should you choose to spend a little more. 

The IBM brand also keeps attracting good people to join so you'll make good contacts if and when they leave.
cons:
Poor salary is the top complaint at the site. Fresh graduates join despite the low pay in hope of a fat bonus (because IBM is a MNC!), only to realise the bonus is really, really, pathetic. Management and HR keeps doing "market surveys" to benchmark salaries, only to consistently adjust them to significantly below market. As a result, the mediocre and terrible stay and move around (even becoming managers), while the great people keep leaving. There are even those who endure the ridiculous salary for 1-2 years just so they can put the IBM name on their resume. 

The number of night conference calls are also frustrating. You are expected to take them to report status to your international counterparts. Some poor souls may take 4 night calls a week!

There are also a number of incompetent people who get lead/manager roles in the company because of the high turnover. They are the most experienced people who stay behind, but they consistently drag the teams down. Management does nothing to resolve this, and consistently reports to the execs that "things are great!".

review_title: If True Innovation is what you seek, don't come here.
pros: The people on the whole, are great, smart people.  The long-time employees here have lots of deep expertise you can learn from, and if you want to get into the tech industry, IBM has very good training programs for those who are just starting out, or just entering the tech industry. IBM is a great start if you'd like to learn what the corporate life is like, and how B2B deals and partnerships are made.
cons: IBM is a huge company with many initiatives, sometimes contradictory to each other. This results in considerable internal fighting, and it takes a long time for initiatives to really trickle down and take hold. The company's internal processes are extremely backwards; the systems and software used to run the paperwork & backend have not changed for many many years. For any other company that may be fine, but this is an IT company that allegedly sells automation and digitize other companies. And as much as it tries to sell the story of "trying to get closer to start-ups" or innovate, not only is the company slow moving, it also very often fails to identify the true failure points of external and internal problems. I have seen time and again new tools, programs, and strategies trying to be rolled out, so much effort, investment, and have no one uses them properly because it fails to innovate the core pain points employees face.

job_title: Business and Technical Talent Lead, AP and GCG in Singapore
pros:
You don't join IBM as just another company - depending on what you want:
1) You can join a library where you draw a wealth of experience from
2) You can join a powerful group of professionals and leaders who are industry experts - ofcourse you need to reach out to them
3) You could join a University - where learning is of utmost importance and you have tools ranging from IBV studies to Bluemine to Books 24X7, Mediahub, Executive Insights, Forums, Seminars, Funded Technical Groups, Professional Communties....the list is endless
4) You join a network unheard of - and a brand who would be proud of no matter which corner of the world you go to. All you say is - I'm an IBMer and I guarantee you will be recognized just for being an IBMer!
5) You will join a matrix, a maze and will be given umpteen keys to sift through it and rise to the top. IBM is for smart professionals. Not for a mundane worker - you will get lost if you are someone who needs instructions to move/work. You basically carve your own career. No one stops you and you can get all the support/mentoring
6) You join a partner and not an employer. Here's an enterprise that trusts you when you need to work from home, need to have flexible hours, need to take care of your kids and join a call at the same time...as long as you're committed and deliver. IBM does not micro manage, You can be an entrepreneur in IBM
cons:
Any other organization after IBM can feel like a downer! You will definitely be valued a lot once you have IBM on your resume but you will find all other jobs very tactical once you've worked in IBM.
It's always tough to exist in a conventional office space type work once you've worked for IBM. You get used to the travel, the openness, the flexibility and the trust the company places in you. It's tough to find that elsewhere.

pros: Still one of the biggest names in the IT industry, though most will agree that IBM is somewhat past its heyday. As such having 'IBM' on the resume will probably open many doors but don't be surprised if recruiters in their 20s have never heard of the company. Fringe benefits provided are one of the best I've ever seen such as fully-reimbursed GP/ specialist visits at panel clinics, free on-site flu vaccinations and the occasional freebies to boost morale (e.g. ice cream, Fitbit tracker, etc). Telecommuting is allowed, in theory. But whether if it's specifically allowed for you will be at your manager's sole discretion and mental state....
cons: Overly bureaucratic but that's kind of expected for a company of IBM's size. Be prepared to execute the same process n times, e.g. entering data into multiple platforms or preparing essentially what are similar reports but modified slightly to cater to various levels of management. In that sense a job at IBM would suit someone who is looking merely at passing time or...keen on exploring archaic and/ or quaint technologies that nobody else uses anymore. The company is using Notes/ Domino for email and Connections as its internal social networking tool instead of the ubiquitous Outlook/ Exchange and Sharepoint. Speaking of Connections, be prepared to be constantly harangued by local managers to go and read and like the posts put up by senior management on Connections. Also, be prepared to parrot the goosebumps-inducing-cadence-calls-of-the-quarter at every opportunity (of course preferably on Connections!) if you are seeking to move up the hierarchy or ingratiate yourself with the management.

The managers are also very flexible and understanding(of course, you need to meet such manager, I haven met manager that is sales-style in the software development work). 
Every year we can hear that IBM has so many patents, and so many achievements, so will feel proud of being part of this company.
cons:
The company is just too big, I feel I have little chance to know better picture of the company, it might need to take 7-10 years to really understand how IBM as a whole company works. 
That leads to the confusion of company strategy. The upper management often talk about strategy, but as a bottom developer, I cannot really feel it is been executed. We are just doing the way we did before, change is very slow. There are too many people giving their opinion  and in the end, progress is made after a lot of meetings. 
Also the patent application process is a bit abused. Sometimes some people is not doing patent for passion or interest, but for promotion. But as I heard from some colleagues, in US, this process is much healthier. 
I also feel we have too many products, as a IBMer I'm also often confused.
Microsoft has moving very fast to re-invent itself. Now IBM need to catch up.

pros:
IBM has a long history of being a pioneer; a company that truly set the bar for delivering a) quality services to clients, b) revolutionary products for the industry, and c) breakthrough innovations and contributions to research. 

This rich history still stands, and the company has an arsenal of patents and technologies that it can potentially tap on.

There's also good talent in the organisation, but unfortunately, stifled and highly underutilized.
cons:
This is a company that needs a change in not just management, but mentality. 

They've missed several big tech waves now, and not for lack of trying - if there's any product/service that has made fortunes for recent B2B tech startups, you can bet that IBM had at least one internal project doing the exact same thing. The difference being that the IBM environment usually kills innovation instead of rewarding it. Management knows very little about what are the strategic next steps to take, and are usually 1-2 years late to almost any party.

The time-delay, in a large part, is because at its heart, IBM is not a tech company. It might have been in the past, but what stands now is the bare facade of a tech company, with the inner workings of a sales organisation. Decision-making is handled by people largely unfamiliar with technology trends, and is not just reactive to the market, it's late, extremely late. And then executed in the worst manner possible with teams that care more about self-aggrandizing themselves rather than good internal coordination. It's no surprise that customers and the market both are confounded. Not to worry, the employees are equally clueless. 

A warning to anyone joining in a decision-making or strategic position - you and your analytical mind will suffer in this company. 

A warning to anyone joining in a technical position - you will think you're being given meaningful work, but after 2 years of solving some of the toughest problems, you will realise your product has been shelved for no apparent reason. 3 years later it will be launched successfully by a startup that will make millions, while your resume would have moved on in a direction you never imagined or wanted.

job_title: Advisory Engineer in Hopewell Junction, NY
pros:
Disclaimer: A lot of what I'm writing below of course depends on the work area and management chain.  But I found this to be fairly pervasive policies in IBM in my 9+ years with the company. 
1. IBM's policies and management are very flexible when it comes to working remotely or accommodating various life situations (sick days, doctor visits, etc.).  Management is encouraged to measure an employee by their work and impact, and not by hours spent at their office. 
2. Great colleagues!  Though unfortunately, many have been leaving due to the instability of IBM's HW development business. 
3. At least in my area, there's a high level of flexibility on which projects should I undertake based on my and my management assessment of business impact.
cons:
1. Unfortunately, IBM still uses the "normal distribution" rating system, where at the end of the year each employee is ranked as a top contributor (5%), above average contributor (15%), average contributor (~75%), and bottom contributor (5%).  This curve is difficult to apply in the R&D world, where you may have many members of the team working long and hard hours, and end up being "average contributors" at the end of the year, because there just isn't room for all to be top contributors. 

2. The above may not be so disturbing, if only IBM didn't practically cancelled all raises, performance bonuses and incentive for the non top-performers. I've had a consistent "above average" rating in the last 4-5 years, and my raise and performance bonus were ridiculous mere 1.5-2% of my salary.  Were I rated "average contributor" I would have gotten NOTHING. So you can imagine that people can go year after year without any raise to their salary.

From talking to manager friend, this is IBM's way to eliminate the non-top-performers without having to fire them, as part of its direction of reducing US manpower. 

3. Hiring freeze in many areas - again, as part of IBM's attempt to reduce its workforce across North America and Europe we see many jobs move to the India and Far East markets.  This is of course upsetting to see local teams shrink and disappear, especially when many great local IBM colleagues and experts begin to drop out. From my experience thus far working with India SW teams - they are still very far away from the standards I would have expected from US and Europe based teams. 

4. Poor top down communication about company's and divisions' future.  Employees learn from rumors and news websites what's about to come...

review_title: Great learning opportunity; Little growth expectations
job_title: Full Stack Web Developer in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros: IBM is an international giant with more than a century of experience and it shows. It has the infraestructure to provide lots of learning resources. It also has very competitive salaries and benefits. It's a great place to settlein if you want a rock steady employer.
cons: There is a lot of learning opportunities but very few chances to apply it. It's hard to push new technologies to be implemented because the client pressure is always up and getting a promotion is difficult to the point where it becomes easier to move to a another job and get rehired in a higher position later. There is also a lot of the baggage and bureaucracy that comes with huge and old companies. For example, they started implementing a back to office mandate. Which affects all of the workers they hired during the pandemic that might need to relocate to a really expensive city like Guadalajara. In Guadalajara the company site is located way outside of the city. Meaning you waste up to 2 and a half hours commuting to and from the office. Mandating to go back and reducing the worker's quality of life is a completely tone-deaf move by an administration that clearly doesn't have the workers well being in mind.

job_title: Director Talent Acquisition in New York, NY
pros: A culture of generally thoughtful, ethical, open and driven colleagues, leaders and subject matter experts across the globe. I've witnessed, first hand, a history of putting our clients needs and our ethics ahead of all else. It's almost impossible to get stale in your career IBM if you are someone who seeks growth and has proven ability to deliver. In my experience, there have been challenges and opportunities around every corner and the work at a global scale is hard, REALY hard at times, but nothing compares to the gratification of achievement. I know I could do similar work at other large tech companies, but it's the people I get to do it with and the ethical foundation our work stands on, that keeps me engaged happy here.
cons: You have to have patience and perseverance to navigate the waters and break through layers of process, protocols and compliance to get major work done . IBM is a finance led company. We will never be the cash cow . Employee compensation is fair/market but no one is trumpeting the horns on bonus amounts. As a leader - It can be brutal at times, trying influence finance to loosen our purse strings for the right investments. It can feel short sighted and sometimes it is. That said, I recognize, we are a tech company that has been in business for 100+ years. Clearly, a history of good business strategy but begrudgingly I also have to give due credit to financial management... no matter how frustrating it can be.

job_title: Application Developer in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Plenty of training and access to a Udemy business account as well as the company paying for certifications.
cons: Management constantly belittling employees causing damage to the mental health of those employees while the behavior is never addressed. Spent over 3 years with the company and they provided me and others with no actual projects, just had us changing training topics every week or two, gaining surface level knowledge without any practical experience. All practical experience I gained was doing projects on my own time after work hours because I was simply told "Learn X on Udemy" This made it incredibly difficult to speak to ones abilities when finding a new job on top of the dread of opening my laptop every day. On top of walking back their remote work policy and having me go back to spending 2+ hours a day in traffic that I could instead be spending with my family. It never felt like a team environment with everyone stuck on Udemy with their headphones on anyway. Got calls regularly on weekend evenings (8-9 pm)to design and develop features that weren't urgent just because one of the architects didn't have anything else to do and wanted us to work on these features right away and not charge the client for those hours worked. Compensation is about half of what it should be and getting a raise is like pulling teeth even if you meet all of the requirements.

review_title: Review from a dev full of ideas
pros: - It's a big company and you have the possibility to grow in whatever direction you want, everyone is happy to help because you are not actually going to take their own position. - In IBM we have also external clients so the internal teams are very united and everybody is supportive and offers help in order to achieve the best version of the project, in the end. - You have free udemy, o'reilly and other learning accounts - You have free vouchers for lots of certifications - Inside IBM there is a specific platform for recognising good employees, and you can receive recognition from coworkers, managers based on your performance and each employee has a specific yearly budget only for giving to others - very interesting projects, big clients and we kinda do something that you can feel it may have a big impact
cons: - Not so much benefits - If you want something, you need to ask because nobody will offer you anything on a silver plate - Lots of corporate trainings

review_title: Amazing teams making an impact on the world
pros: - You work with incredibly smart and prepared people, but who are not scared to learn something new and say "I don't know". - It's very flexible, I've been working from home or some form of hybrid for 10 years now, and with just a simple conversation with your manager you can define what works better for you both. - Challenging work, with a lot of tools to help you get there, complete support from management to experiment, try things out, fail and iterate. And I pretty much define what I will work on, how and when, depending on the requests the team may have. - I love love love my team. Love spending time with them, love working as a team to get stuff done. We meet virtually just to chat once a week, to know how we are, thing's we've done, our families, etc. To spend time together. - Given the scope of the company, you get a chance to be in global roles and you do not need to be a super-high-up-in-the-hierarchy leader to do so.
cons: - IBM is super focused on compliance, so we get mandatory trainings or processes we must complete to ensure it is so. - Being such a big company, having teams span the world, sometimes processes are a bit bureaucratic, although I feel it has changed a lot in the last years.

review_title: Trash Company with too many managers
pros: IBM gives you more and more work, but due to inflation and no pay raises for years upon year, you end up making less and less money. Is this a pro? Of course not, but glassdoor forces you put something down as a Pro.
cons: Lots of incompetent managers. Management does no real work. They just cook up bad ideas about things they know nothing about. Then makes their team implement their bad ideas. Management is getting rid a lot of US workers and moving these jobs to other countries like India and Mexico to save a buck, while holding on to their own jobs. They threatened their employees to get a vaccine or stop working. They made a vaccine policy based on Joe Biden's unconstitutional mandate. They likely did this due to further reduce employees numbers in the US. IBM lost employees without finding replacements for them. The work gets passed to current employees, and IBM refused to compensate employees for taking on additional work duties. IBM made employees take Diversity & Inclusion training similar to Coca-Cola's training that educated employees "To Be Less White" I seen IBM's first hand practices of hiring large amounts of young employees. They called it Vitality Hiring. After the new younger employees got their training from older, more seasoned workers, IBM would have massive amounts of layoffs. Of course, the older higher paid employees get laid off, while the new young employees were safe from the layoff. IBM is a disgraceful company, don't be fooled by their fake reputation of being a honorable company. They are far from it.

review_title: Fun place to work if you're willing to invest in a career
job_title: Software Engineer (Band 7) in New York, NY
pros: - The work-life balance is decent and the workplace culture is modern. - Pay is fair for the work being done. - For the most part, coworkers are helpful and approachable, but as with everywhere, YMMV. - Opportunities for growth, although they need to be sought out. Employees are encouraged to take on side projects and contribute back to IBM (and beyond) so long as their primary obligations aren't impacted. - Decent career potential if staying at a company for over 5 years.
cons: - HR is practically non-existent. - A high turn-around in more junior positions leads to unqualified individuals attaining high ranks simply because they stuck around. Experts on issues are few and far between. - The organization is so large that duplicate work gets done frequently, primarily due to poor collaboration between departments. - Teams aren't given any technical direction, so in most cases, tech stacks will vary significantly from team to team.

review_title: Not a great place for mothers
pros: Good salary and benefits but expect you to work outside contracted hours
cons: As soon as I came back working part time from maternity leave (used to be full time prior to maternity leave) the company made me redundant and gave the minimum statutory redundancy which was 1 week for every year I had been there. I had been there almost 10 years. Previous years redundancy packages were a lot more generous but the company has become more and more ruthless towards staff over the years I was there. Great company at the start but towards the end just another corporate monster placing undue pressure on employees squeezing the life out of them for little reward. Replacing UK staff with cheaper Indian staff and The Indian staff were treated even more poorly, very hierarchical and expectations to work unsociable hours (out of contract hours) as a norm with no compensation and told not to submit those hours on the timesheets, just pretend to work standard hours. All in all, you get worked to death and if you are part time and a mother, you’ll be made redundant.

pros: Payslip is good . No much communication on mail so you are not going to waste time on reading mails. Access to many learning sites like udemy.
cons: Process wise not good inside IBM.They hire people from outside without having project in their hand.Later they make you sit idle or send you bench .You may not get proper responses from your manager or WFM when you are on bench. Here HR department not helpful. If you got project fortunately or unfortunately then later your manager may release you after 3 months just giving any nonsense reason. And if you're a woman employee having kid ,manager thinks you don't work no matter how many change requests you complete or you attend how much hours of meetings or supported in calls. Manager behaves like a boss and make you feel like slave. They never try to understand your situation or your problems or team problem. Though IBM have good leave policy ,your manager will not approve or allow you to take leave or use your leave. And if you have kid at home and you need any kind of emergency leave for your kid your manager will say you can't take leave for this reason or that reason etc.

review_title: they will kill your ambitions very quick

review_title: IBM's inclusive culture and many opportunities to grow and learn new skills
pros: The two biggest pros to me are the inclusive culture and strong connection with fellow IBMers and management, and the endless opportunities to grow and learn new skills. For culture, IBM truly lets you bring your authentic self to work. I feel completely comfortable in being who I identify with, and there are so many resources for employees to connect with other IBMers. I always feel that my colleagues, manager, and leadership team provide an open and welcoming environment for everyone, regardless of race, ethnicity, sexual orientation, or gender identity or expression. I just feel that I can be myself and ask questions and be open with others. I can't tell you how many deep conversations I've had with my direct managers about my personal and professional goals. They always listen, and I mean truly listen, to my thoughts and plans and always offer feedback, and sometimes just lend an ear if I need to talk to someone. And regarding growing my career and learning new skills, the opportunities at IBM are endless. We have frequent check-ins with our managers where we receive constructive feedback about our accomplishments and areas to improve. Open communication is always happening. We also have an internal learning platform where I can take online courses and watch videos on a variety of skills to help me improve my knowledge base and increase my skill set.
cons: Working for IBM has been the best experience of my career. Every company has a few things that can improve, but nothing here that I would label a "con". I truly love my job, my manager, my colleagues, and the leadership in my division (Talent Acquisition) and look forward to working here for a long time.

pros: Able to influence key decision makers at client to make a technology decision that's alignment with their strategic goals. Be the task master and influence your coders and other doers to deliver consistently, and above their weight category so they can grow faster. And frequently coax them to go above and beyond.
cons: If you can connect, network, and be the bull in the technology "china" shop. then you are on your way to success. Keep watching your 6.

review_title: Would you be opposed to working in a flexible environment with great people?
job_title: Talent Acquisition Sourcer in Bogota, Cundinamarca
pros: Hi, I'm Troy Mcclure. You may remember me... well actually I'm actually not Troy, but What can I say, IBM is my dream company, of course it has flaws like any other company, but IBM owns their mistakes and provides not only a "political acknowledgement," but also takes action, so I know I can trust IBM, its transparent etical and moral in their decisions and procedures, a great place to work, with great flexibility and people who make your day shine!
cons: Ah so you thought I wouldn’t put my cons eh? Naughty naughty. So here's the deal: the cons are there, of course, but they are linked to basic human flaws, so it's difficult not to list the common ones like "oh no there was a miscommunication" or "I never received this email" but aside from that, the biggest flaw of IBM is that we have a lot of opportunities and resources to grow but we don't know how to use them and it can be a sloppy process. Aside from that, it is extremely difficult to obtain extra budget for celebrations or awards such as birthdays or internal activities we create, so don't expect the Big Bee to provide unlimited funds for extra activities.

review_title: Poor Culture but great technology stack , world class education track
pros: Diverse Technology Stack , leverage access to financial services , great education track An amazing partner ecosystem
cons: -Poor culture , plenty of new hires and summits , but old guard still in charge. Must be a suck up to get rewarded. -Top Performers get targeted by older employees maintaining control of key administrative positions without any knowledge of what happens with clients -Diversity games shield real racism , company divided into camps based on race , while encouraging outside affiliates to follow through with agenda - claim to be agile , but consolidates on a few individuals who run the company as a water fall signings organization - claim to be ethical, but leverage their size to influence market through a few voices - Talent does not get rewarded and only those close to management get recognized for their work.

job_title: Associate Application Developer in Lansing, MI
pros: IBM is so focused on learning. They offer hundreds of thousands of free courses on Udemy and O'Reilly. Managers will also get you setup with courses with live instructors teaching. Everyone at the office I work at is set on finding a project for you. Until you find one, just soak all the knowledge that you can, it's offered to you and encouraged. While you are "on the bench" (not on a project) and most projects, everyone is extremely flexible. Everyone has a life outside of work and mostly everyone knows that. I think this is a fantastic environment and place to work. I'm proud to be an IBMer.
cons: I can't really think of one. However, I do want to talk about 1 con that I have seen a lot. IBM does require on some projects that you work 45 hours week. There is a reason for this. Remember all of that free education you received, that certification you didn't pay for that will follow you anywhere you go, the paychecks you received during this, when all you have done at this point is cost the company money? This is where you make up for it. Now that you are generating income for IBM, that extra hour a day is your repayment. 1000% Worth it if you ask me. I would have spent thousands of dollars on the courses, live classes, and certifications I have received, if it wasn't for IBM investing in me.

pros: — Take care of their employees. At least, here in Mexico. This company offer benefits above the law. — The community is great, you can join or create communities and interact with them. For example, in IBM I contacted the creator of the package Scanmem and GameConqueror which is used to hack video games on Linux. —Free platforms for learning, is the best. I have Udemy for free, for any video. I got 3 Cloud certifications for free (Red Hat, AWS, Azure), basically IBM spent $8,000 USD in my professional knowledge. And, I'm going for more certifications and more knowledge.
cons: — Big companies always lost the track for each employee. I mean, you can disappear between plenty of employees, which is equal to not promotions, or tracking about your career. — Do a lot of extra administrative work for mandatory trainings, timesheets, request vacations, travel expenses, etcetera.

pros: Impressive footprint with large clients, so very likely you will make a great difference from many people.
cons: A supertanker driven by New York. If a country lead wants to do things differently, it will have to be approved by someone in NY which is rather unflexible.

cons: -Too many mandatory administrative and required irrelevant education sometimes. - Distracting to support too many client at a time sometime. pros: As an Associate Consultant, I have jumped right into building my career, all while focusing on serving the client and growing the IBM Consulting practice. IBM is a place for young professionals who are will to say yes to the call, seek to serve the needs of others, and individuals who have a growth mindset. Each day as a Consultant can look a little different, whether it is printing documents for the client or even presenting in front of key industry leaders, IBM will give you the platform to harness skills that will develop your leadership capabilities and enhance your business acumen, all while allowing you to voice your personal career goals.
cons: At IBM, we seek to build client trust above all else. While that can be a highly rewarding and build a lot of your professional growth, it also limits the bandwidth I have to dedicate to internal IBM initiatives. Balancing client work alongside IBM work is something many Consultants find hard to discern, however, there are so many leaders with more experience willing to help give actionable advice to combat the challenge.

review_title: Remote work making the experiece super boring - office is empty

cons: Finance team is scattered around the world, so your manager, teammates may be in NY, Latin America, or Europe and you will never see them or have happy hours after work. The Rochester site is hell for young people, a small midwestern town with no culture or nightlife, the only other big firm in town is a catholic hospital, so be ready to live amongst a money-loving, church-going population.

review_title: Review for IBM from an 1.5y employee
pros: - free access to Udemy & other learning platforms - chance of being part of multicultural teams - schedule relatively flexible - chance to work from home completely (hope it stays such, otherwise I might leave) - periods when no work is required exist, which is both a pro and a con - private medical insurance available for some money that's deducted from the salary
cons: - some People Managers are not made for being People Managers due to lack of empathy and tendency to lean towards the interests of the company rather than on those of the employee he/she manages - periods when no work is required exist, which is both a pro and a con - salary could be bigger - there is no 13th salary (as Christmas compensation) - there are no lunch tickets given - schedule is 9am-6pm, so you are left with very little personal time (could be 9am-5pm with 30min lunch break, that extra hour as free time is precious)

job_title: HR Partner in Rio de Janeiro
pros: I joined IBM as an intern and it was a great opportunity to change my life. I didn't come from a renowned university, nor did I have any referrals, but the IBM recruiting and management team was able to assess my development potential and it was the chance I needed to get where I am. IBM is a big and very unique world, which does have its challenges like every company, but it offers the tools to work well and develop our careers: a channel to find your coach or mentor, very practical guides on how to have your career conversations , a portal full of skills development resources, just to give some examples. Besides, of course, the benefits and salary, which I am very satisfied with.
cons: As a big company, bureaucracy is something to keep working on. IBM is prioritizing simplification & productivity with many practical examples of improvement.

pros: 1️⃣ Pre-Onboarding: I was extremely impressed by the organization and efficiency of the initial onboarding process; everything was submitted and completed using a variety of online tools. It was reassuring that my health insurance, pension plan, badge and equipment considerations were completed before I began my role. 2️⃣ Initial Onboarding: At this stage, I knew my training program and was granted access to rich information regarding my role as well as being introduced to my line manager, who also greeted me on my first day. 3️⃣ Focused Orientation and Training: The focused orientation and training has been invaluable and I am now fully aware of the roles and responsibilities required for my new position. 4️⃣ Mentoring: I have been assigned a mentor who has been exceptionally helpful supporting me with any questions surrounding my role and the overall onboarding process. 5️⃣ Nurturing and Self-Paced Learning: This has been a mixture of approaches and practices, including online presentations, virtual workshops, interactive videos, recorded sessions and exams. This accelerated my learning curve tremendously. 6️⃣ Employee Development Programs: #IBM have a dedicated platform for career development, skills progression and career growth. For instance, you can decide your next career opportunity and simply work towards it. 7️⃣ IBM Culture: In simple words…#THINK. 8️⃣ The CSM Role: There is so much to learn about being a #CSM. Just within my first two weeks, I have learned about RedHat Openshift, Hybrid Cloud so much more!
cons: Nothing, everything is amazing here!

pros: good and personal development was good
cons: difficult to get into a role of your choice

pros: There is good development projects
cons: Manager driven company, even though you work with full dedications and there will be always demarkation with respect to the work. Work life balance is difficult as you need to work on weekend to meet the delivery and your project manager decide the delivery date which you have to meet otherwise there will be escalations. IBM is like a manager-driven company; if you have good terms with your people manager, then it will go smoothly; otherwise, you will be in trouble. Even without any reason, you will be put into the PIP. If you provide the justification for the PIP being raised against you, you will not receive any response from the people manager. Ideally, PIP would last for 60 days, but if your people manager wishes to extend it for the next 2 months, he can do it and no one can question him. If, mistakenly, you reached out to HR for the same, then you will see a lot of escalation emails.

pros: They have good learning program that you can take up when you have free time.

It was worse because my on boarding happened when everyone was working from home. I’ve on boarded manyyy employees while being remote in my prev company, but this place clearly has no clue on how to run on boarding smoothly while being remote.

job_title: Data Engineer in Rio de Janeiro
pros: It`s a big company, with dozens of departments and a well structured organization. We have easy access to higher level managers and they have genuine behavior of help (even if the necessity to scale questions is more frequent than should be). IBM allows you to change you career area and stimulates continuous growth, what is nice. Time is flexible in most of the projects and the managers mind the mental health and family matters.
cons: There`s some excess in governance and control policies and a lot of time is spend in governance tools and calls. Salary is in the market average, but a big company, with big clients and contracts, should pay above that, like some other blue chips. I feel missing the opportunity to work for international clients with multi-country teams, as other consulting companies do. Everything is regionalized. The same applies for the opportunity of a country change, it`s very rare, what is frustrating for a company that has a so large leverage across the world. In general, I feel IBM needs to modernize the governance in the same innovative way we work technically every day.

pros: English speaking company Benefits includes massages They have good values, but they apply them until it is convenient for them
cons: Very situational in Q2C and BPM in Slovakia. Their approach after Covid19 is the following, they do not replace people that leave. Instead they offer to the people that stays to double their workload for no immediate salary increase. You may get a laughable salary raise (+80€) after 6 months or more for doing the double of the work and more importantly, if you refuse, you are out. Also, they do not fire directly, but they normally put you in so uncofortable conditions, that you will leave and they can still look "good" because they did not fire you but they pushed you to it. All the theories about Agile, promoted company values, to give space to staff ideas and so on are just marketing in IBM Slovakia, unless you are dying, stay away from IBM Slovakia expecially in Q2C / BPM departments.

pros: Availability of Training/Education Ability to work on some very large projects
cons: Poor Remuneration, 1 (tiny) wage increase in 4+ years, 2 "bonuses". (At my current job I've had 1 wage increase in 5 months - and the pay was better to start with) Long hours (ever worked a 36 hour shift?) IBM products are terrible and there's no interest in improving them. IBM ONLY cares about the bottom line - not doing the right thing for the customer. Releasing buggy software improves the bottom line if they can delay telling the client about the issue for long enough to get through the warranty period. You are entirely expendible. If you put a gun in your mouth and pulled the trigger, IBM would collect the insurance and move on.

review_title: Professional and skilled employees - IT hardware boring
pros: Talking about IBM CIC Groningen: - People are very open-minded, young and dynamic - Employees are very skilled, and can develop new skills - Direction is professional and honest, communication is fair and transparent
cons: Talking about IBM CIC Groningen: - As a consultant, people often work alone on their project, or with colleagues from other locations (Amsterdam for example). This reduces opportunity of team building - Since the covid, people stay working at home, so that office is quite empty and annoying - IBM CIC signed a partnership with Apple for hardware (computer and phones). IT environment is terrific since Apple products are not user-friendly, and in my opinion, not convenient for our projects development. On top of that, most of our Client use Windows environment system, which ends regularly with tools incompatibility between us and our Client/Partner - There is not good IT support, so that we more rely on experience of our peers to fix IT issues than calling IT who answered 99% of the time that they don't support our request. - It is not possible to buy refurbished computers from the company in the Netherlands Despite these cons, it is nice company to work for

job_title: Principal Solution Architect in Hartford, CT
pros: IBM is very flexible with work/life balance and provides abundant education, and career-growth opportunities. IBM's total compensation is very competitive, and always improving. IBM's technology portfolio is best of breed and strives to satisfy client needs. IBM's work environment is very inclusive.
cons: IBM's virtual education portfolio should also include more traditional classroom and lab formats enforcing hands-on bootcamp-style learning. IBM's management mandates too much data-entry with project tracking that drives employee measurement metrics with no indication of the outcomes. IBM has become too political and has adopted a woke culture that seeks to raise awareness of specific groups while making others feel guilty when they are innocent. IBM tends to lead from behind and focuses too much on the finances versus the technologies, and listens more to Wall Street than Main Street. IBM fosters an environment that creates internal competition by over communicating the successes and gains of employees who reach career milestones that they want to enforce, like certifications.

review_title: Good or bad depending on the people and the project
pros: They offer career development courses and certifications, free of charge. You can get to work on some interesting projects and increase your hands-on technical experience. However, my experience has been that the workload is very heavy and you don't have enough time to complete courses and certifications in the work time. They do however expect you to study in your free time to pass them. If you don't do that, you will have a very hard time advancing from a salary point of view regardless of how well you do in the actual project you are paid to work for.
cons: My recent experience has been that it's a very political environment. It's full of non-technical managers which do alot of talking but don't lift a finger to help solve procedural issues for the team. At least I'd expect them to be very good on the soft skills side, but my experience has been that that is the exception rather than the rule. Most of the time, in order to increase in salary it does not matter how good you are or how much effort you put in, but who you know and how well you can package a mediocre result. Some managers are faking emotional inteligence just because it looks good and seems politically correct but you can see right through it. Don't expect yearly salary increases regardless of how well you perform - they won't even keep up with inflation.

pros: The history of the company and its name
cons: -Some of the leaders do not seem to have the appropriate skills to lead. This causes confusion in the employee and a huge lack of motivations -very low salaries in comparison to other big IT companies

pros: I am writing this after one year of my joining at IBM. What I feel here, like 1. One of the best organization with great Brand value, you get a good impression when you say "I am an IBMer". 2. Environment and Equality at work is the best thing here. 3. Good Learning opportunities and growth scopes are available with proper guidance. 4. Nothing fixed about your role/position. We have a option to change our position to our interested field but off course you should have knowledge of that field. 5. In some cases we can change our work location also as per our choice. 6. Whatever talents you have, you can showcase here. 7. Any specific work hours (Like 9 hrs or 8 hrs) is not mandatory here. If you have completed your task and you have nothing to do, you can leave by informing accordingly.
cons: We have to follow quite lengthy process for everything (Including Interview & Joining process, Documentation and even your day to day work). BUT Its a very large organization so to maintain everything for Audit/Repository/Security, IBM has to have a set of rules everywhere. So, we shouldn't consider it as Cons. review_title: IBM has great career opportunities and a supportive environment
pros: There are multiple career opportunities in many directions, both through changing location and staying in a single location. The company greatly values integrity, both with customers and employees. Excellent work/life balance, with additional fun activities subsidized by the company for those who are interested. Innovation is supported in everyone. Management is not the only career path. There is also a very strong technical path. IBM offers something for every level of experience, from student to those with 40 years of experience. IBM supports all of its employees, including working location -- from home/office/hybrid.
cons: There is always bureaucracy in a large company, and IBM is no exception. While the bureaucracy keeps things organized and allows the perks that are offered to employees to be used by all, it can be a little annoying. Low performers are eventually asked to leave but sometimes it can take a while due to periodic limitations on backfilling or hiring.

review_title: Going to need to drag me away from IBM. I'm a lifer.
pros: IBM is a huge proponent on Personal Growth. You have an incredible amount of continuing education courses available to you. To build upon your current skills and learn new ones that will help you land your next gig at IBM. Lots of positive attrition with in the company. You become a lifer, because there are so many opportunities with in Big Blue. -Work Life Balance -Lots of positions allow you to work remotely -Competitive Pay (and above market compared to a similar positions at many other local tech companies. ) -Incredible peers -Great collaboration between teams, when you're in an office it's an open work space. -Paternity leave / parental bonding is 12 weeks paid leave for fathers too. -This is the first job where I've had managers assist you with moving on to "better and bigger" things, supporting you through your journey and advancing your career. I've worked with the same team for 5 years now, and have moved up the ladder with in, while watching coworkers solidify new opportunities with other teams with in IBM. The positive attrition is amazing.
cons: No Cons at this time. In 2022, IBM raised the salaries of many positions to continue to be above those of the other Tech companies in the area. This effort to stay competitive, during a time where the economy was in a down turn and the cost of goods and housing had substantially increased for employees.

review_title: Opportunities to learn at scale and work with some amazing talent, but at a cost.
pros: Learning to do anything at a large company and run an organization effectively at scale is a significant skill gain. Bonuses--when paid--were quite nice, and upper management is compensated well.
cons: Old management styles reign. Very few women in leadership roles. When looking at budgets, there is no apprehension by upper management to make employee cuts versus alternative solutions. Business units are continually changed and shifted with new leaders and new objectives preventing true forward growth and momentum. I had 7 leaders in 5 years.

job_title: Business Operations Manager in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros: 1. People - 95% of the people I've worked with are kind, respectful, patient, true professionals, and it is a pleasure to work with them. 2. Opportunities - you have many options to "develop your craft" within the company, train, get certified, and in case you ever "get bored" of what you do, you can even jump laterally to a different department, different role, there's a lot of room to grow here. 3. Managers - the managers I've had throughout the years are open, honest, you can always bring forward your concerns, ask for guidance or help. 4. Stability - IBM is a huge corporation, it won't "die out" anytime soon, you don't have worries about what will happen with your job tomorrow. 5. Flexibility - a. as long as you do your job, you can (mostly) work what hours you want / b. if you work from home, you can even relocate to a different city. 6. Employee benefits - while other companies may offer a budget for buying sports goods or professional chairs, IBM has the IBM Badge program - a list of vendors in different areas (restaurants, fashion, travel, electronics, automotive, etc) for which IBM employees have discounts (5-20%). On the long run, I think you get more out of this than any other fixed budget.
cons: Salary First of all, I don't think IBM has aligned to the market that well, I still believe we're somewhere between 10% and 40% below market in terms of salary, depending on the role / job. Secondly, there is the issue of attrition - employees that have been with the company for a longer period of time, don't get recognized (salary-wise) as much as new hires. You get small raises from one year to another, but those usually don't even cover inflation. Would be good to keep the "loyal" employees more satisfied, so that they don't end up leaving.

pros: Plenty of upskilling opportunities and training provided. Tie up with numerous online portals where on can take courses free of cost.

Some Account executives literally sleep every single day in office even during customer meetings (yes- literally sleep and snoring...). However even they will be shielded and no actions taken even when proof is provided and reported to ethics team in IBM. infact such managers will be awarded with "Manager Champion award" and promotions!! 4. You can survive only if you have a God father higher up. It doesnt matter how good or hard you work.. 5. You will not be allowed to move out of the account even after more than 10 yrs (same manager/account as i indicated above- in Public sector- healthcare account). When they finally decide to let you move out, you can be rest assured your rating for the year is completely screwed to meet their low performance rating "targets" for the year.

pros: IBM is a great name to have on your CV and to get experience with a large corporate. As a company, it prioritises learning and provides many resources to gain additional knowledge. As a consultant, I was obliged to spend a minimum amount of hours just on courses. This was great and I got to travel to conferences, hackathons and trainings abroad to do so as well.
cons: Overall, IBM was going through some difficult years positioning itself as a business. It placed a big bet on AI, specifically, their natural language processing engine named Watson. It was simply not mature yet to be sold to enterprise clients, especially with fierce, more specialised competitors in AI solutions. The result was that as AI/data science consultants, we had to scramble for interesting projects to work on. Even though IBM wanted to invest in talented young grads like me at the time, I felt rather bored and suffocated by the internal politics.

review_title: My best employer in 25 years of my career in IT
job_title: Senior Customer Success Manager in Tucson, AZ
pros: * Streamlined onboarding process * Zero micromanagement * Compelling company's mission * Teammates always have your back * Competitive salary * Self-education is encouraged * Direct access to cutting-edge technologies * Working with the pool of SMEs * Transparency at career grow path or changing roles
cons: *Do not freak out, if you are at the start of your career and surrounded by people at their 40s or 50s. IBM employees tend to stay with the company for a long time. Think of it as a benefit (or opportunity) and ask colleagues about IBM history, their roles, career tips and advices * You may feel lost at the beginning of your work at IBM, especially due to WFH. Try to get in touch with your teammates on a regular basis, find some hobby buddies or join a virtual club - IBM is huge and provides lots of opportunities to team up!

pros: To start it is very good. They train and teach you, they give you the tools to be able to learn on your own what you want and that may or may not serve your current position and perform in office. Excellent for gaining experience and at least in the area of ​​development your colleagues always support you and share their knowledge with you. The job is fun and you learn new things every day. Home office in some areas and depending on the type of client.
cons: The pay is very poor, below market. There is no possibility of accessing significant salary increases or changing areas, which is one of the things that they promote and promise you when you enter. Being a consulting company, they do not place limits on the client when dealing with the employee. There is constantly a transfer of responsibilities by the client, they tend to blame you for things that go wrong even if it's not your fault and your PM usually does nothing.

job_title: VP Business Development in Boston, MA
pros: I spent 2 decades with IBM - but in many different roles and on many different brands. The quality of the IBM employees and the integrity with which they conduct themselves and their business is among the best I saw over my long career. Access to professionals, in an environment that is very data driven and logical made for a great learning experience. And there are few places where you can work in any number of industries, anywhere on the global in any number of functional roles. It is a great career development experience.
cons: Risk taking and enabling people to "fail fast" while trying new ideas in uncharted waters would allow some new innovative thinking. Plus there are many employees whose goal seems to be perseverance or self preservation instead of all in on company success. With over 400K employees it is to be expected but should not be tolerated.

job_title: Talent Acquisition Partner in Austin, TX
pros: Now I come from an agency environment, so it wouldn't be too difficult to beat my prior working experience. That being said, I am consistently impressed with IBM for the following reasons: 1. Autonomy: IBM managers do not hover over you and micromanage your performance. We instead depend on a lot of internal tools to get and give feedback on performance. Communication with our clients and managers is largely left up to us (with guidance), and the feedback from our managers is what is tantamount in our reviews. 2. Work load balance: gone are the days where I have too many reqs to handle. And because I'm assigned to a particular skill set within a business unit, I am able to hone in on my talent pool and also dig in deep to a skill set to get to know. I'm also able to move around, so the skill sets I am exposed to gets broader and deeper the longer I'm here. 3. Education access: IBMers tend to stick around because of the ability to learn entirely new skills through the robust and large internal education program. If your dream is to do something other than your job down the road, there's plenty of opportunity to learn brand-new skills--even learning to code! It's really up to you as an individual to choose your path within IBM.
cons: 1. The lack of bonuses year over year is a killer when trying to recruit candidates from outside IBM. Even with our best year yet for our shareholders, we will not be seeing competitive bonus incentives. 2. Return to office push: can we please just give up on this? I understand that it is a huge change due to real estate that is owned, but employee retention and satisfaction is much higher when we allow folks to work from home. The pressure to return to office is also much higher on the softer ("easier to replace") skill sets, so this pressure is leveraged against your lower banded positions, where higher banded and more niche skills get much more leeway. 3. Compensation ratings for some cities are just wrong. Austin should not be at a "national" market level, given our rising cost of living pushing many employees out of the city center. Although leadership may be paid to live in the city center, your professional banded positions are not paying enough to be able to live close to the office, or to purchase property within the city.

job_title: Business Transformation Consultant in Copenhagen, Capital Region
pros: IBM offers great flexibility and the access to training is unseen anywhere else. I've been able to get earn several certifications and develop skills in different areas throughout my career at IBM.
cons: IBM will tell you that they are "people business" - that is probably the biggest lie. It used to be true - at least to some degree. But nowadays, all the fun and things that bring people together is completely gone. So if you value Friday bars or other regular social events with your colleagues, then IBM is not a place for you. All focus is on profit. Furthermore, people are often left on their own since people management is almost gone. That is true both for new joiners and people returning from leave.

review_title: A good place to start but not to stay
pros: Good pay & benefits, great place to learn
cons: They got in to SF by buying BlueWolf. By the time I left, I was pretty much the last remaining "pack" member who was an SA. There's a good reason - they steadfastly refuse to understand the unique nature of SF and SF projects. As a result, they believe that any PM/BA can be an SF PM/BA, and so most projects are poorly staffed & run - and guess who has to pick up the slack? However, if you're careful, you can mostly stay on the bench your first year and learn, learn, learn! Pile up certs, learn the consulting business, and keep one eye on the door.

cons: By its size, IBM has a lot of employees and it is sometimes difficult to navigate to find the right people. New joiners would need more guidance and coaching as part of their onboarding, which is unfortunately too light at the moment.

job_title: Senior Technical Staff Member in Albany, NY
pros: IBM has always had a reputation for attracting and hiring the best. That is evident in all interactions with your peers. They are smart, helpful, and care about solving the problems, more than getting accolades. IBM provides lots of tools for bettering your career and yourself. It has as much of a "Small Family Company" feel as is possible, with the local management empowerment, despite its size. Another benefit is that IBM really rewards performance, not pedigree. IBM advances it's employees to titles, roles, and responsibilities commensurate with their abilities, and has similarly limited others with better credentials. Most accept and celebrate this, not begrudge it.
cons: It is a big corporation.. there are global corporate policies (hoops to jump through) from everything from software procurement to annual appraisal, but overall, they are reasonable.

review_title: Life would be nightmare if allocated to worst project
pros: Nothing much of pros except work life balance, remote work flexibility and few show off bombastic technologies which lacks poor team management and team structure skills
cons: Pathetic senior management, don’t understand the value of different roles and technologies and think themselves as “IBMer” as someone having God level software’s engineering skills. Leads and managers don’t even know how to manage proper resources in proper place. You would be randomly assigned in a project where you will be randomly asked to work in any skillset no matter from what background you belong. For example a dev might be directly assigned with a devops work all of a sudden, without any training or KT, A SDET might be assigned to development all of a sudden without KT, an SDE assigned to manual testing all of a sudden and then again a change from that role to another role in the next sprint. Now if they are unable to perform they will be abused by some managers saying “you should learn and grow”. Let me tell this thing, “learn and grow” means learn new technology in your technology domain not change of domains all of a sudden and then again a change in the next 3 months. One will end up in becoming Jack of all trades but “Master of None”. Change is good but not from sprint to sprint. No salary hikes, you will retire with the same CTC with which you joined Team management and team structure is the poorest I have ever seen. Worst than a lot of small start up companies even. Unstructured projects, managers think about short term goals only. Almost no managers know what is the role of “SDET” but they hired SDET. Alas !!!!!
